title: Coffee Butter Frosting Recipe
description: This coffee buttercream frosting is sure to be a favorite for java lovers everywhere. It mixes up quickly and can be used on any type of cake or cupcake.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Desserts Frostings and Icings Chocolate Coffee Butter Frosting 4.5 (226) 176 Reviews 41 Photos This coffee buttercream frosting is such a treat for coffee lovers! With its delicious mocha taste, it's perfect with chocolate, caramel, or white cakes. Submitted by GINGER P Updated on May 3, 2023 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 41 41 41 41 Prep Time: 10 mins Total Time: 10 mins Servings: 16 Yield: 2 cups Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 16 servings 1 ½ cups powdered sugar 1 tablespoon unsweetened cocoa powder ⅓ cup unsalted butter, softened 1 tablespoon strong brewed coffee Directions Whisk powdered sugar and cocoa powder together in a bowl. Beat butter in a medium bowl with an electric mixer until creamy, 2 to 3 minutes. Gradually add powdered sugar mixture, beating well after each addition and scraping the sides and bottom of the bowl occasionally. Add coffee and beat until smooth. I Made It Print 367 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Coffee Butter Frosting 01 of 41 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 41 Photo by  Michelle Knights 11/17/2020 03 of 41 Photo by  rachel 05/01/2020 04 of 41 Photo by  Geri St Lucia 02/08/2020 Easy and delicious! I used coffee extract instead of the brewed coffee. Super good on brownies! 05 of 41 Photo by  Patti Boltz 02/23/2019 I was searching for a caramel frosting recipe for black magic cake cupcakes when I ran across this. Checking the reviews, several of them said they couldn’t taste the coffee. Using my Kuerig, I brewed a 4 oz cup set on strong (Dunkin Donuts if it makes a difference). Then I boiled it down by about half in the microwave and doubled this recipe. I was just shy of enough butter so I added a couple tablespoons of cream cheese as I was originally planning a cream cheese frosting on them. I ended up using more powdered sugar than 3 cups due to a little extra liquid and then I kept the frosting on the “soft” side. Not runny but thin enough to just dunk the cupcakes to frost. I can definitely taste the coffee and this recipe is just delicious. Thanks for posting it! 06 of 41 Photo by  Avery Bohm 11/30/2018 Omgggggg I was so in love with this frosting . You have to try this! 07 of 41 Photo by  Marian Danielle Pineda 09/13/2017 Read a few of the helpful reviews. Used the tip of one of the reviewers to triple the amount of the cocoa powder and coffee. My final feedback is that the buttercream frosting, as an individual product, it tasted a little bit too sweet for me but very rich in the “coffee” flavor, which I liked very much. Since the frosting is already sweet, I reduced the sugar in the dark chocolate (sponge) cake I baked. After assembling the cake, I also put salted caramel on top. The sponge cake and caramel sauce helped lessen the sweetness of the frosting. The cake, as a whole, was 100% perfect. 08 of 41 Photo by  jillianlaura 03/13/2017 09 of 41 Photo by  Morgan 02/24/2017 Fantastic and easy recipe! I followed the other reviews and doubled the coffee in there, because I really wanted a stronger coffee flavor. I piped this onto chocolate cupcakes and dusted with some espresso powder for a final kick, and they were perfect! 10 of 41 Photo by  Krisha 11/02/2016 It ended up being great, but only after significant alterations in proportions. I ended up having to add another quarter cup of margarine or so, and only used about two thirds of the cocoa-powder sugar mixture. I do prefer my icings on the slightly less sweet side and have the tendency to alter icing recipes, but this was to a larger degree than I usually have to. I also added three tablespoons of coffee until I could taste the flavour. I think this recipe is a good starting point, but I'd go into it with the mindset that you might have to alter proportions as you go (add the sugar gradually and taste as you go). That being said, the icing I ended up with was fantastic. Perfectly sweet (or unsweet, rather) to my taste, good but not overpowering coffee flavour, and very easy to use to frost a cake. It applies very smoothly and isn't too soft so it sets well, but does not harden. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Homemade Chocolate Frosting 101 Ratings Buttermilk-Chocolate Buttercream Frosting 5 Ratings Fluffy Chocolate Buttercream Frosting 5 Ratings Perfect Chocolate Buttercream Frosting 7 Ratings Best Ever Nutella Frosting 4 Ratings Basic Chocolate Buttercream Icing 55 Ratings Mocha Frosting 41 Ratings White Chocolate Buttercream 2 Ratings Granny's Mahogany Cake and Frosting 12 Ratings One Bowl Buttercream Frosting 252 Ratings Chocolate Fudge Buttercream Frosting 637 Ratings Creamy Chocolate Frosting 2,420 Ratings Mint Buttercream Frosting With Dark Chocolate Glaze 89 Ratings Coffee Frosting 43 Ratings The Best Chocolate Glaze 106 Ratings Mocha Icing 109 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: GINGER P
instructions: Whisk powdered sugar and cocoa powder together in a bowl.;Beat butter in a medium bowl with an electric mixer until creamy, 2 to 3 minutes. Gradually add powdered sugar mixture, beating well after each addition and scraping the sides and bottom of the bowl occasionally. Add coffee and beat until smooth.
